Prompt:
Example 1:
Cat and Dog walk. They walk in their village. Then they see an egg. The egg is in the grass. The egg is alone in the grass. The egg is all alone. Cat and Dog walk to a bird. They ask the bird, "Is this your egg?" But the bird says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the owl. Maybe it is his egg." Cat and Dog walk to the owl. They ask the owl, "Is this your egg?" But the owl says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the goose. Maybe it is her egg." Cat and Dog walk to the goose. They ask the goose, "Is this your egg?" But the goose says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the two ducks. Maybe it is their egg." Cat and Dog walk to the two ducks. They ask the two ducks, "Is this your egg?" But the two ducks say, "No, that is not our egg." Then the egg breaks.

Example 2:
The Sun’s light shines on Earth. The light makes our air, land, and water warm. But some things get
warmer than others.
Pretend it is a sunny day. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a white shirt, you wouldn’t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun’s energy. That makes the black shirt warm.
Light colors reflect more of the Sun’s energy. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper. You also need two thermometers and a lamp. Ask an adult to help you.
Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Turn the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers.
Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'computer security' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 150 words. Explain that computers can be kept safe from harm by following some simple rules.

Computers are like pets. They need protection. Bad people can hurt them. They can steal your games and pictures. To keep computers safe, follow these rules. First, use a strong password. It should be long and have different letters and numbers. Next, don't click on strange links. They might have viruses. Always update your computer. This helps keep it safe. Lastly, never tell your password to others. Keep it a secret. If you follow these rules, your computer will stay safe.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'computer security' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 150 words. Here is a sentence starter: "A computer and a person sit together."

A computer and a person sit together. They work. Then they see a virus. The virus is on the computer screen. The virus is alone on the screen. The virus is all alone. The person and the computer ask an expert, "Is this your virus?" But the expert says, "No, that is not my virus. Ask the firewall. Maybe it is its virus." The person and the computer ask the firewall, "Is this your virus?" But the firewall says, "No, that is not my virus. Ask the antivirus software. Maybe it is its virus." The person and the computer ask the antivirus software, "Is this your virus?" But the antivirus software says, "No, that is not my virus. The virus is all alone. It is not anyone's virus." Then the virus disappears.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'computer security' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 150 words. Avoid using jargon.

A computer is like a house. When you want to enter a house, you need a key. A computer needs a password. This is like a secret key. Only you know it. A computer can get viruses. These are bad things that make a computer sick. An antivirus is like a doctor. It helps the computer feel better. A hacker is like a burglar. They try to break into computers. A strong password is like a strong lock. It keeps hackers out. Always use a strong password to keep your computer safe.

They ask the bird, "Is this your egg?" But the bird says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the owl. Maybe it is his egg." Cat and Dog walk to the owl. They ask the owl, "Is this your egg?" But the owl says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the goose. Maybe it is her egg." Cat and Dog walk to the goose. They ask the goose, "Is this your egg?" But the goose says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the two ducks. Maybe it is their egg." Cat and Dog walk to the two ducks. They ask the two ducks, "Is this your egg?" But the two ducks say, "No, that is not our egg." Then the egg breaks.

Example 2:
The Sun’s light shines on Earth. The light makes our air, land, and water warm. But some things get
warmer than others.
Pretend it is a sunny day. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a white shirt, you wouldn’t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun’s energy. That makes the black shirt warm.
Light colors reflect more of the Sun’s energy. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper. You also need two thermometers and a lamp. Ask an adult to help you.
Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Turn the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers.
Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'computer security' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 150 words. A computer is a machine that stores and processes information. It is like a brain that can do many things, like play games or help with schoolwork. To protect the computer, we need to keep it safe from bad things, like viruses. A virus is a bad program that can harm the computer. It can make the computer sick, just like how a cold can make you sick. To keep the computer safe, we need to have good computer security. This means we need to have a good firewall, like a gate that keeps bad things out. We also need to have good passwords, so only people we trust can use the computer. By having good computer security, we can keep our computer safe and healthy, just like how we keep our body healthy by eating good food and getting enough sleep.
